forumNotes.content:
Hello **NicKMind**   
Most of your questions are answered in the FAQs  
[http://www.msfn.org/...howtopic=116766](http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showtopic=116766 "External link")  

> First question, Can I use the link below to create a USB stick for installing Windows 2003 Server? Should I be able to install 64-bit versions of XP and 2003?
Yes, see FAQ5  

> I'm having a problem with BSOD in TXT mode right after "Starting Windows" message  
> BTW, its a Dell Optiplex GX620.
Especially for Dell computers you will need to use a modified NTDETECT.COM - See FAQ3  

> Sometimes I am only getting one installation from a USB stick, then I have to recreate the stick to work again. Why is this happening?
Some files are deleted from stick in case of Windows 2003 - See FAQ5  
You don't have this problem if you make use of:  

**Install XP from USB AFTER Booting with PE from HDD or USB**   
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=5306](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5306 "External link")  

> Last question, When the program asks me if I want to make the drive U:, i click yes, but when I go to install I still see the drive taking drive C: on new HDDs. How can I fix this?
From Tutorial:  
> New Harddisk and Creating Partitions after Booting from USB-Drive:  
> Direct after Deleting and Creating New partitions, Quit XP Setup with F3   
> OR Switch OFF your Computer and Boot in any case from USB-Drive again and   
> Run 1. TXT Mode Setup again so that DriveLetters get their **Correct Value**   
> So in this case one Boots \*\* **TWICE** \*\* in the TXT-mode Setup XP

forumNotes.author: wimb
forumNotes.content:
> If we are saying "yes" to that question of making the drive U: . Then why do we have to boot Twice. Isn't the reason why we are being asked the question?
No.  
In the case of Creating Partitions during XP Setup, you have to Boot TWICE with TXT-mode so that the Drive Letters of your **Harddisk** get their correct value. Initializing by BIOS and XP Setup is essential in this case.  

The Drive Letter U: refers to your **USB-stick** and takes care that your USB-stick is NOT Shifting the Drive Letters of additional Logical Drive partitions of your Harddisk.
